attributes.comment:
After reading the testimony given by the USCIS Director, Emilio Gonzalez, I have a
hard time grasping it. While it makes sense that those applying for immigration
benefits in this country should have to foot the bill for those services, it still does
not seem reasonable to me that the government should raise these fees by over
60% when most immigrants trying to make their way in this country can hardly
afford the fees as they stand today.

Immigration is something that is close to me as it affects someone that I know.
And when this person is able to apply for permanent residency in this country, I
imagine that we would be willing (or forced) to pay whatever is necessary to
achieve the residency he has been seeking for over 5 years. Why is it the US is
so strict on keeping families apart? Good, solid, hard-working families that don't
commit crimes, don't take advantage of the system, they are people that just want
to provide a life for their family - yet the United States gov't cannot seem to agree
on reinstating Section 245i so that multi-race families can live like American
families, not in the shadows, not scared to do something in fear, but free and not
held back from a better job. The United States has to recognize these people.
They have to recognize the blended families where one part is an American citizen
and the other is a citizen of another country. Why must we as a whole suffer along
with those that are breaking the law? We are only trying to survive, only trying to
lead a comfortable life, yet the gov't takes their sweet time deciding on something
which only forces those families to struggle until a decision is made that will allow
those families the same equality in this country that other American families have.

Why is it that everytime immigration is discussed in the news no one ever hits on
the topic of illegal immigrants that are married to US Citizens? Why is that? Are
these people not important? Do they not deserve something more then the illegal
aliens that are coming here to take advantage of our state systems and the like? I
believe that they do deserve more. I only wish that the people sitting in the seats
at a gov't level would only feel the same. Why not help these people first? And
then tackle the problem of the aliens that are here illegally and taking advantage of
the systems the US has in place? Why must the good suffer for something the
bad are doing?
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Angela Cordova
